instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.2V5_NAND: What is 2V5_NAND? This is a power rail that powers the SSD that is soldered onto the logic board of Macbook Pro models with a soldered on SSD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> short to ground
threads.message:
[B]Received condition:[/B]
Tea spill, damage near the NAND area. The Voltage was stuck at 5v.
[ATTACH type="full" width="271px"]60055[/ATTACH] [ATTACH type="full" width="270px"]60056[/ATTACH]

[B]After the cleanup:[/B]
- Cleaned the whole area. There was a lot of crap underneath the <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>, so removed it. 2 pins were gone.
- Connected power, 5V and 200mA, the <CAPACITOR>C9080</CAPACITOR> was heating. Heard a crack, removed <CAPACITOR>C9080</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C9081</CAPACITOR>.
- Connected power, 19V and 65mA. But all the caps on the <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> are completely short to the ground.

[ATTACH type="full" width="273px"]60057[/ATTACH] [ATTACH type="full" width="272px"]60058[/ATTACH]

Not sure what to do next? 
In past, I have seen multiple <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with NAND short issues.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> short to ground
threads.message:
Overvoltage went from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>2V5_NAND</SIGNAL>, through <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>.
SSD is dead now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> short to ground
threads.message:
Did I cause this?
What should be done now? I mean, is SSD replacement a viable option?.

In my experience SSD short on this model is becoming one of the most common issues.
I searched on YouTube, didn't find any videos on this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> short to ground
threads.message: SSD died because of corrosion, not your fault.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> short to ground
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> short to ground
threads.message:
Hopeless project.
Apart of NANDs, must replace the controller, which comes in sandwich package.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> short to ground
threads.message:
That's sad :(
But anyways, thanks for your support.
